prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main objective of this tuning is to obtain measurements of 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1). In addition, this set-up will enable observations of SiO(5-4), H(30)alpha, and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
I. Sensitivity
We estimate the expected strength of 13CO(2-1) based on the molecular survey of the Magellanic Clouds (Heikkila et al. 1999). Based on the ALMA SV observations of 12CO(2-1), we adopt an 13CO(2-1) strength of ~8-10mJy, and we request and rms of 0.8mJy. In order to keep observing time at a reasonable level, we will allow for slightly lower spectral resolution of 25km/s (which will not significantly degrade the observations).
II. Imaging
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, we estimate the size of this cloud to be < 0.4" (or ~40pc). In order to resolve this cloud on a size scale that is closely matched to that of super star clusters, we request the a synthesized beam of 0.20" (or ~20pc).
III. Correlator Set-up
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, the velocity dispersion of this source is quite large (FWHM > 100km/s), thus high spectral resolution is not required. Even when resolved into substructures, the size-linewidth scaling for turbulent molecular clouds (delta_v ~ sqrt(L)) suggests linewidths in Cycle 2 of > 70 km/s. Thus, we only require spectral resolution of ~10-20km/s. We plan to integrate the line emission over 20km/s intervals. The spectral window locations have been adjusted to simulataneously observe lines as well as sensitive continuum observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main objective of this goal is to obtain measurements of HCN(3-2) and HCO+(3-2). In addition, we wish to obtain continuum measurements.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
I. Sensitivity
We estimate the expected strength of HCN(3-2) based on the molecular survey of the Magellanic Clouds (Heikkila et al. 1999). The strength of HCN relative to 13CO varies depending on how "active" a particular region is. Here we adopt an HCN(3-2) strength of ~3.5mJy, and we request and rms of 0.35mJy. In order to keep observing time at a reasonable level, we will allow for slightly lower spectral resolution of 25km/s (which will not significantly degrade the observations).
II. Imaging
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, we estimate the size of this cloud to be < 0.4" (or ~40pc). In order to resolve this cloud on a size scale that is closely matched to that of super star clusters, we request the a synthesized beam of 0.20" (or ~20pc).
III. Correlator Set-up
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, the velocity dispersion of this source is quite large (FWHM > 100km/s), thus high spectral resolution is not required. Even when resolved into substructures, the size-linewidth scaling for turbulent molecular clouds (delta_v ~ sqrt(L)) suggests linewidths in Cycle 2 of > 70 km/s. Thus, we only require spectral resolution of ~10-20km/s. We plan to integrate the HCN line emission over 20km/s intervals. The spectral window locations have been adjusted to simulataneously observe both HCN and HCO+ as well as sensitive continuum observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main objective of this science goal is to obtain measurements of 13CO(3-2) and C18O(3-2). In addition, the tuning is set to also observe H(27)alpha and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
I. Sensitivity
We estimate the expected strength of 13CO(3-2) based on the molecular survey of the Magellanic Clouds (Heikkila et al. 1999). Based on ALMA SV observations of 12CO(2-1) and our Cycle 0 observations of 12CO(3-2) we adopt an 12CO(3-2) strength of ~15mJy, and we request and rms of 1.5mJy. In order to keep observing time at a reasonable level, we will allow for slightly lower spectral resolution of 25km/s (which will not significantly degrade the observations).
II. Imaging
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, we estimate the size of this cloud to be < 0.4" (or ~40pc). In order to resolve this cloud on a size scale that is closely matched to that of super star clusters, we request the a synthesized beam of 0.20" (or ~20pc).
III. Correlator Set-up
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, the velocity dispersion of this source is quite large (FWHM > 100km/s), thus high spectral resolution is not required. Even when resolved into substructures, the size-linewidth scaling for turbulent molecular clouds (delta_v ~ sqrt(L)) suggests linewidths in Cycle 2 of > 70 km/s. Thus, we only require spectral resolution of ~10-20km/s. We plan to integrate the HCN line emission over 20km/s intervals. The spectral window locations have been adjusted to simulataneously observe both HCN and HCO+ as well as sensitive continuum observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN(4-3)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main objective of this science goal is to obtain measurements of HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3). In addition, this set-up will enable observations of CS and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
I. Sensitivity
We estimate the expected strength of HCN(4-3) based on the molecular survey of the Magellanic Clouds (Heikkila et al. 1999). The strength of HCN relative to 13CO varies depending on how "active" a particular region is. Here we adopt an HCN(4-3) strength of ~4.0mJy, and we request and rms of 0.4mJy. In order to keep observing time at a reasonable level, we will allow for slightly lower spectral resolution of 25km/s (which will not significantly degrade the observations).
II. Imaging
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, we estimate the size of this cloud to be < 0.4" (or ~40pc). In order to resolve the detailed structure of this cloud and the dense gas regions, we request the highest possible resolution, or ~ 0.12".
III. Correlator Set-up
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, the velocity dispersion of this source is quite large (FWHM > 100km/s), thus high spectral resolution is not required. Even when resolved into substructures, the size-linewidth scaling for turbulent molecular clouds (delta_v ~ sqrt(L)) suggests linewidths in Cycle 2 of > 70 km/s. Thus, we only require spectral resolution of ~10-20km/s. We plan to integrate the HCN line emission over 20km/s intervals. The spectral window locations have been adjusted to simulataneously observe both HCN, CS, HCO+ as well as sensitive continuum observation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main objective of this science goal is to obtain observations of 13CO(1-0) and C18O(1-0). In addition, this set-up will enable observations of CS(2-1) and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
I. Sensitivity
Based on our Cycle 0 observations of 12CO(3-2), and the SV observations of 12CO(2-1) and the expected temperature of the cloud, we estimate the the total 13CO(1-0) flux density of this source to be 40mJy. We estimate the source size to be roughly 0.4", which will be slightly resolved with the best resolution available at Band 3 of 0.37". Therefore, we expect a surface brightness of ~20mJy/beam. In order to reach a S/N of 10, we request an rms of 2.0mJy.
II. Imaging
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, we estimate the size of this cloud to be < 0.4" (or ~40pc). Thus we seek the highest available resolution at Band 3 of 0.37" (or ~40pc).
III. Correlator Set-up Based on our Cycle 0 observations, the velocity dispersion of this source is quite large (FWHM > 100km/s), thus high spectral resolution is not required. Even when resolved into substructures, the size-linewidth scaling for turbulent molecular clouds (delta_v ~ sqrt(L)) suggests linewidths in Cycle 2 of > 70 km/s. Thus, we only require spectral resolution of ~10-20km/s, and we plan to integrate the 13CO line emission over 10km/s intervals. The spectral window locations have been adjusted to simulataneously observe not only 13CO(1-0), which is our primary target, but also CS(2-1), C18O(1-0), and sensitive continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main objective of this science goal is to obtain measurements of HCN(1-0) and HCO+(1-0). In addition, this set-up will enable observations of H(42)alpha, H13CO+, HC17O+, HC3N, and SiO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
I. Sensitivity
Based on our existing CO measurements combined with the approximate temperature and density of the cloud, we estimate the expected strength of HCN(1-0) to be ~3mJy and we request an rms of 0.30mJy. In addition, to we will allow for slightly lower spectral resolution of 25 km/s (which will not significantly degrade the observations) in order to keep the observing time at a reasonable level.
II. Imaging
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, we estimate the size of this cloud to be < 0.4" (or ~40pc). Thus we seek the highest available resolution at Band 3 of 0.47" (or ~40pc).
III. Correlator Set-up
Based on our Cycle 0 observations, the velocity dispersion of this source is quite large (FWHM > 100km/s), thus high spectral resolution is not required. Even when resolved into substructures, the size-linewidth scaling for turbulent molecular clouds (delta_v ~ sqrt(L)) suggests linewidths in Cycle 2 of > 70 km/s. Thus, we only require spectral resolution of ~10-20km/s, and we plan to integrate the HCN line emission over 20km/s intervals. The spectral window locations have been adjusted to simulataneously observe not only 13CO(1-0), which is our primary target, but also H42alpha, H13CO+, SiO, HC17O+, HC3N, and HCO+.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This ALMA proposal requests observations to probe the birth environments of globular clusters. In our Cycle~0 observations, we identified an extraordinary molecular cloud in the overlap region of the Antennae interacting galaxy system. This cloud has the properties required to form a globular cluster (including size and mass), but there is no evidence of the onset of star formation in our VLA centimeter observations. The discovery of this singular molecular cloud represents a major leap forward, and we now have the opportunity to determine the physical conditions in a pre-globular cluster molecular cloud -- before these conditions have been disrupted by star formation -- for the first time. Here we propose six separate ALMA tunings from Bands 3 to 6 that will provide observations of a rich array of key diagnostic lines. This extraordinary dataset will enable us to determine the temperature of this cloud, measure the dense gas using multiple tracers, determine the mass of the cloud using CO isotopologues, resolve the cloud's physical structure, look for evidence of shocks, and determine the underlying dust spectral energy distribution and dust-to-gas ratio.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: The Antennae: A Luminous Stellar Nursery (P.I. Whitmore)
